p: Millets are an important source of food for humans and feed and fodder for animals in the arid and semi-arid tropical regions of Asia and Africa. Considering cultivated area and production, finger millet, pearl millet, foxtail millet and proso millet are the most important millets. Pearl millet accounts for > 50% of the global millet production. In Asia, it is mainly grown in South and East Asia and in Africa, mainly in the Sahel. Pearl millet occupies > 95% of the total millet area in Africa (16.8 million ha). The West and Central African region has the largest area under millets and the six major pearl millet producing countries in Africa are Niger, Nigeria, Mali, Chad, Burkina Faso and Senegal. Average productivity in the region is 880 kg ha − 1 with Nigeria having the highest productivity. In Eastern and Southern Africa, pearl millet is cultivated on about 2 million ha, with productivity ranging from 800 kg ha − 1 to 920 kg ha − 1 ( Bhagavatula et al., 2013).
